title: How to punctuate dialogue examples - Quora

response.answer_text: Dialogue: Each person speaking gets a new paragraph. Spoken words are written between quotation marks. e.g. A little boy sat on the curb, wailing. The nurse crouched beside him and said, “Hello, my name is Judy. What’s your name?”2. “Billy.” 3. “Did you hurt yourself, Billy? Is that why you’re crying?” 4. “I can’t find my mommy. She went into the big tent,” he said, “and she didn’t come out yet. I need to pee and she told me to stay right here. If I leave she won’t know where I went and I don’t know what to do. 5. “Please, lady, will you help me find my mom?” 6. “Of course I will,” the nurse said. “Here, have a tissue.” Note the words in Bold: When I broke the quotation after “tent” in paragraph 4, to put in the attribution (he said), then carried on, I didn’t use a capital letter for the word “and” because it was a continuation of the child’s sentence. Note the bit in Bold italics: Because Billy was still speaking I did not close the quotes at the end of paragraph 4, but opened paragraph 5 with quotation marks and closed it because that was all Billy said. This is the correct punctuation of quotations in dialogue when one speaker needs a new paragraph for the rest of his speech. He needed a new paragraph because it was a new train of thought, It’s always a good idea to read published novels that have a lot of dialogue so you get the hang of punctuating it.

“Hello”! “Hello. I’m Amy. What’s your name?” “I’m Joe. Are you a friend of Bill’s?” “Yeah.Actually, we’re all friends of Bill. He’s a great guy.” “Are you going anywhere later? “No.I’m going home to bed. Alone. “Oh. Me, too. “Bye”. “I could change my mind?” “Too late. Here comes Sarah. I wanna talk to her, OK? ‘Bye.”.
